data_findings.finding: This is a 2D polygon packing optimization problem. Goal: pack Christmas tree shapes (15-vertex polygons) into smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200. Score = Σ(s_n²/n). Lower is better. Target: 68.919154. Current best from snapshots: 70.676102.

bbox3.cpp is the core optimizer: uses Complex Number Vector Coordination, Fluid Dynamics simulation, Hinge Pivot mechanism, Density Gradient Flow, Global Boundary Tension. Compile with: g++ -O3 -march=native -std=c++17 -fopenmp -o bbox3 bbox3.cpp. Run with: ./bbox3 -n 10000 -r 64

tree_packer_v21.cpp: Alternative optimizer with swap moves, multi-angle restarts, higher temperature SA, squeeze/compaction/local search phases. Uses long double precision. Run with: ./tree_packer_v21 -n 5000 -r 16
fix_direction post-processing: Rotates entire configuration to minimize bounding box using convex hull and scipy.optimize.minimize_scalar. Critical for final optimization.

Backward propagation (bp.cpp): Improves smaller N configs by removing trees from larger ones. Start from N=200, work down to N=2. For each config, try removing boundary-touching trees and keep if (N-1) config improves.

CRITICAL: Pre-optimized santa-2025.csv is at a very tight local optimum. Short optimization runs (minutes) find NO improvements. Top solutions run for HOURS with 15000+ iterations and 80+ rounds. Need much longer optimization or fundamentally different approaches like lattice-based packing.

3-Phase optimization strategy: Phase A (short runs 2min, n=1000-2000, r=30-90), Phase B (medium runs 10min on top candidates), Phase C (long runs 20min on best few). Uses fix_direction + overlap repair after each phase. Keeps best submission, reverts on regressions.
